Rodrigo stands: "I'll gather everyone, Your Majesty. Give me ten minutes." He strides out, and you hear his voice echoing through the palace courtyard: "All crusaders! Assembly in the main courtyard! Full company, now!"

You walk out to the large courtyard. The afternoon sun slants across the cobblestones. Within minutes, men begin streaming in - some from training, some from the barracks, some from prayer. They form up in rough ranks, adjusting their new white tabards, looking curious and slightly anxious.

García and the other guards position themselves at intervals. Sir Thomas stands to one side. Fray Hernando moves among the men briefly, then takes his place.

Within ten minutes, all sixty-two crusaders stand assembled. Marco and the veterans help organize the less experienced men into proper formation. The eight leaders you just met with stand at attention in the front rank.

The men fall silent, watching you expectantly. Behind them, Diego returns with a heavy chest and two guards helping him carry it - the treasury funds you requested.

The courtyard is quiet except for distant Barcelona street sounds and the fountain's trickling water.

What do you say to your assembled crusaders?

Soldiers of Christ,


You have answered the call. You have taken the pledge before this holy banner and before allmighty God. And you have placed your faith and trust in the crusade and me that you will be provided for. You have pledged your service without discussing pay or demanding any. I will adress this issue right now and repay your faith.


Every soldier of Christ will be paid 2 maravedis per day or 60 maravedis per month. You already know that you pledged your service for as long as it takes to take all of Grenada. The moment we complete our crusade, I will divide the lands among our faithful christians. Crusaders will be among the first to be rewarded. I will let you know later how much this is going to be.


You have all come here, some with posessions, others with only their body and soul. A soldier makes sure he is also adequately clothed and made ready. I will give every crusader an one-time payment of 200 maravedis so everyone can buy a warm cloak, a good pair of boots, or do whatever they want with it. This is a one-time payment only, after one month, you shall all recieve 60.


Diego, our treasurer, will now pay you all. Accept these payments and spend them wisely.

The courtyard is absolutely silent as you speak. Sixty-two men stand transfixed, hanging on every word.

When you finish, there's a moment of stunned quiet. Then it breaks.

"LONG LIVE THE KING!" Marco's voice rings out first, powerful and clear.

The entire company erupts: "LONG LIVE THE KING! LONG LIVE THE CRUSADE!"

Some men are shouting, some are weeping openly, some drop to their knees in prayer. Andrea is crying, his young face overwhelmed with emotion. Giovanni clutches his rosary, tears streaming down his weathered face. Pietro is grinning ear to ear. Even the veterans like Alonso and Pedro look moved - hardened soldiers clearly not expecting this generosity.

Miguel Cardona, the nobleman, looks genuinely impressed. Brother Guillem makes the sign of the cross and bows his head in thanks.

Diego steps forward with the chest. "Form a line! One at a time, state your name clearly!"

The men organize themselves quickly, excitement barely contained. García and Rodrigo help maintain order as the line forms.

One by one, the crusaders approach. Diego checks each name against his list, counts out 200 maravedís - a substantial sum for common soldiers - and hands over the coins. Each man clutches his payment like treasure, many making the sign of the cross, some bowing deeply to you before stepping aside.

"God bless you, Your Majesty," mutters one.
"I'll fight to the death for you, sire," promises another.
"My family will eat this winter," whispers a third, voice breaking.

The payment continues. The men who've received their coins gather in small groups, counting and recounting their money, discussing what they'll buy, making plans. The energy in the courtyard is electric - gratitude, loyalty, and fierce determination radiating from the assembled crusaders.

Fray Hernando watches with satisfaction. Sir Thomas nods approvingly - you've just bought extraordinary loyalty for a relatively modest sum.

The last man receives his payment. Diego closes the chest and bows to you.

The sixty-two crusaders stand in the courtyard, white tabards gleaming, coins in their hands, eyes on you with devotion that goes beyond mere duty.

What do you do?

events.summary: Captain Fernán successfully delivers Juan's arrest orders to Álvaro in Valladolid after a 14-day hard ride (success roll). Álvaro publicly summons the Infantes to surrender for trial on September 5, but the arrest attempt FAILS: the Infantes publicly refuse, claiming the orders are forged; they withdraw to separate fortified positions; a three-day standoff at Arévalo ends with Álvaro withdrawing. The Infantes had been intercepting correspondence and were prepared. Alfonso V of Aragon threatens war if his brothers are harmed. The Infantes remain free and defiant but exposed as refusing royal justice, with ~5,000 troops and support from the Master of Santiago.

exchanges.text:
Hi,


I want to determine the action and measure of success of me sending the captain ahead to Alvaro with special instructions.


The aim of the action was to send him fast to Alvaro so he can put out a warrant for the arrest of the infantes. The action does not include Alvaro trying to arrest the infantes, just if the captain is successful in reaching Alvaro and if the messsage and the order is recieved correctly.


Determine how likely I am to succeed.

The mission is straightforward: three experienced men (Captain Fernán has been with Juan throughout, proven loyal and capable) riding fast to deliver a message to Álvaro de Luna in Valladolid.

Factors in favor of success:
1. Captain Fernán is experienced, loyal, and has been Juan's military commander
2. Three riders traveling light and fast - harder to intercept
3. Direct route from Barcelona to Valladolid is well-established
4. They have royal authority if challenged
5. Álvaro de Luna controls Valladolid and the royal administration
6. The mission is simple message delivery, not complex political maneuvering
7. Two weeks is reasonable time for the journey

Potential obstacles:
1. The Infantes have been intercepting correspondence (though Juan doesn't know this yet)
2. Road hazards - bandits, accidents, weather
3. The Infantes have some support in northern Castile
4. Horses could go lame or riders could fall ill
5. The Captain could be recognized and detained

However, the interception network seems to be focused on written correspondence through normal channels, not fast riders on direct royal business. Captain Fernán is competent and traveling with two guards. The route from Barcelona to Valladolid, while long, passes through mostly controlled territory.
 
I assess the mission's probability as moderately high - strong advantages counterbalance potential risks. The strategic advantages outweigh the potential obstacles, making success more probable than failure. While challenges exist, the mission's core elements - speed, royal authority, and competent leadership - provide a solid foundation for accomplishing the objective.

Looking at Captain Fernán's mission to deliver the arrest warrant to Álvaro de Luna, let me assess the probability of success.

Probability Assessment: Likely to succeed

Factors in Your Favor:

Captain Fernán's proven competence: He's been your loyal commander throughout the journey, knows how to handle himself

Three-rider configuration: Harder to stop than a lone messenger, can help each other if problems arise

Speed and light travel: Riding hard with minimal baggage makes them difficult to intercept

Álvaro's control of Valladolid: Your destination is firmly in friendly hands with your Constable in charge

Clear, direct route: Barcelona to Valladolid is a well-traveled road through mostly stable territory

Royal seal and authority: The letter bears your official seal - anyone who interferes commits treason

Potential Obstacles:

Two-week journey: Long distance means more opportunities for mishap - thrown shoes, lame horses, illness

The Infantes' northern influence: Parts of the route pass near territories where the Infantes have supporters

Standard road dangers: Bandits, bad weather, accidents are always possible

Political tensions: News travels - the Infantes may have watchers on major roads looking for royal messengers

Unknown interception network: (Though you're unaware, the Infantes have been reading your correspondence)

Assessment:

This is a straightforward military courier mission - the type Captain Fernán has likely undertaken before. He's traveling with support, on fast horses, with clear orders and destination. While the journey is long and some risk exists, barring bad luck or unexpected Infante interference, he should reach Álvaro successfully.

The real question isn't whether the message reaches Álvaro, but what happens after - though that's beyond this action's scope.

Please roll your dice to determine the outcome of Captain Fernán's mission.

I just rolled and it's a success.


Now we know that Alvaro has recieved the order to arrest the infantes and bring them to trial for rebellion against the crown.


Determine how likely this is to succeed so I can roll.

The arrest order is arriving in early September (Captain Fernán left August 19, two weeks travel).

Factors to consider:
- The Infantes are still powerful princes of Aragon
- Arresting them could trigger civil war
- They have military forces (~5,000 troops total)
- They have warning systems and spy networks (intercepting correspondence)
- Álvaro is competent but this is extremely provocative
- Juan gave Álvaro discretion ("proceed only if there are grounds for trial")
- The Infantes are weakened but not defeated
- They're members of Aragonese royal family

This is a very dangerous action. The Infantes aren't just nobles - they're princes of Aragon, one is King of Navarre. Arresting them is essentially declaring war on the Aragonese royal family.

Looking at Álvaro de Luna's attempt to arrest the Infantes de Aragón on charges of rebellion, let me assess the probability of success.

Probability Assessment: Likely to fail

Major Obstacles:

The Infantes are forewarned: Their spy network has been intercepting your correspondence (though you don't know this). They likely know arrest orders are coming

They're Aragonese royalty: Not just Castilian nobles but foreign princes - Infante Juan is King of Navarre, both are brothers to Alfonso V of Aragon

They still have military force: ~5,000 troops between their households and allied nobles - enough to resist arrest

Their strategic positions: They control Arévalo fortress and have retreated to fortified estates, not caught in the open

International implications: Arresting them risks war with Aragon and Navarre

Noble uncertainty: While 60% of nobles stayed neutral, forcibly arresting princes might push them to pick sides

Physical difficulty: The Infantes aren't at court where they could be easily seized - they're on their estates with armed retainers

Factors in Álvaro's Favor:

Royal authority: He has legitimate arrest warrant from the king for proven rebellion

Control of administration: Commands royal forces and major cities

The Infantes' weakened position: Their revolt failed, they're politically isolated

Álvaro's competence: He successfully defended the realm, he's politically skilled

Discretionary orders: You wisely gave him flexibility ("proceed only if grounds for trial")

Some noble support: 30-35% actively support the crown

Assessment:

While Álvaro has legal authority and the Infantes are weakened, actually arresting royal princes with military forces on fortified estates is extremely difficult. They're not courtiers who can be seized at dinner - they're armed princes who likely know you're coming. Álvaro might successfully demand their surrender, but physically arresting them seems unlikely without triggering open warfare.

The most probable outcome is a tense standoff rather than successful arrests.

Please roll your dice to determine what happens when Álvaro attempts to execute the arrest warrant.

The result is Failure.


Draft the result of both actions and what happens keeping these results in mind. Describe developments in Castille until the end of September when Juan is expected to arrive in Sevilla and will learn about what happened in Castille.

1. Captain Fernán's successful journey
2. Álvaro receiving the orders and attempting to execute them
3. The failure of the arrest attempt
4. What happens in Castile through September
5. The situation Juan will find when he arrives in Seville

The Infantes have been intercepting correspondence, so they likely knew this was coming. The failure means they weren't arrested but it doesn't have to be catastrophic - just a failure to achieve the goal with some negative consequences.

Timeline:
- August 19: Fernán departs Barcelona
- Early September (around Sept 2-3): Fernán reaches Valladolid
- Early-mid September: Álvaro attempts arrests
- Mid-September: Fallout from failed arrests
- Late September: Juan arrives in Seville and learns what happened

Let me craft this narrative.

The Captain's Ride and the Failed Arrests

August 19 - September 28, 1430

Captain Fernán's Mission (August 19 - September 2)

The Hard Ride

Captain Fernán Alonso de Robles, with Martín and Felipe, departed Barcelona at dawn on August 19th. They rode like men pursued by demons, changing horses at way stations, sleeping only when absolutely necessary.

Day 4 (August 22): Crossed into Aragonese territory near Lérida. Local garrison noted their passage but didn't interfere - the Consell Reial's safe passage held.

Day 7 (August 25): Entered Castilian territory near Soria. Fernán relaxed slightly - home soil at last. They pressed harder, knowing they were close.

Day 10 (August 28): Felipe's horse threw a shoe badly. They lost six hours finding a farrier in a small village. Fernán paced like a caged wolf.

Day 14 (September 2): Exhausted, saddle-sore, but intact, the three riders clattered into Valladolid's main gate. Guards recognized the Captain immediately.

"Christ's blood, Fernán! We thought you were with the King!"

"I am. Where's Don Álvaro?"

"The palace. He'll want to see you immediately."

Delivering the Orders

Álvaro de Luna received Fernán in his private study within the hour. The Constable looked older, worn from months of holding the kingdom together.

"Captain. I assume this isn't a social visit."

Fernán handed over the sealed letter. Álvaro read it twice, his expression darkening.

"Arrest the Infantes. On charges of rebellion." He set the letter down carefully. "His Majesty understands what this means?"

"He was very clear, my lord. They rebelled while he was on pilgrimage. They must face consequences. Though he also writes you should proceed only if there are grounds for trial."

Álvaro stood and walked to the window overlooking the city. "Oh, there are grounds. They seized royal fortresses. They attempted to rally the nobility against the crown. They portrayed His Majesty as unstable." He turned back. "The question isn't whether they're guilty. It's whether arresting them is possible without starting a civil war."

"What are your orders for me, Lord Constable?"

"Rest. Eat. Sleep in a real bed. I need to think about how to execute this. And Captain... well done. Fourteen days from Barcelona is exceptional time."

Álvaro's Attempt (September 3-10)

The War Council (September 3)

Álvaro assembled his most trusted advisors:

Diego López de Stúñiga, commander of royal forces

Juan de Daza, treasury official and intelligence gatherer

Count Diego Gómez de Sandoval, monitoring noble factions

Bishop Juan de Cerezuela, Álvaro's ally in the Church

"The King has ordered the arrest of the Infantes de Aragón for rebellion," Álvaro announced.

Silence. Then Diego López spoke: "They're at their estates with at least 2,000 household troops. We'd need to assault fortified positions."

"Or we could summon them to appear," suggested the Bishop. "Publicly demand they present themselves for trial."

Juan de Daza shook his head. "My sources say they've been expecting something. They've been strengthening their positions, calling in debts, securing supplies. They won't come willingly."

Count Sandoval added grimly: "Several neutral nobles have received letters from Infante Juan. He's claiming the King has been 'bewitched' in Rome, that Álvaro is using forged orders to eliminate rivals. Some are listening."

The Public Summons (September 5)

Álvaro chose the middle path. In Valladolid's main square, heralds proclaimed:

"By order of His Majesty Juan II, King of Castile and León: The Infantes Don Juan and Don Enrique de Aragón are hereby summoned to present themselves to royal justice to answer charges of rebellion, seizure of royal property, and conspiracy against the crown. They have ten days to surrender themselves peacefully. Failure to appear will be considered admission of guilt and act of continued rebellion."

The proclamation was copied and sent to every major city in Castile.

The Infantes' Response (September 7)

A herald arrived under flag of truce from Arévalo fortress with the Infantes' reply:

"We, Juan and Enrique, Infantes of Aragón, deny all charges of rebellion. We acted to preserve the stability of Castile during our cousin's extended absence, when he abandoned his realm for foreign adventures. We question the legitimacy of orders issued in the King's absence and demand to see His Majesty personally before submitting to any proceedings. We will not surrender ourselves to Don Álvaro de Luna, whom we consider party to this conflict rather than neutral arbiter of justice."

They also sent copies of their response to every major noble house, the Archbishop of Toledo, and King Alfonso V in Naples.

The Failed Arrest Attempt (September 10)

Álvaro had to act. He assembled 1,500 royal troops and marched toward Arévalo, the nearest Infante stronghold. But when they arrived, they found:

The fortress fully garrisoned with 800 men

The Infantes' allied nobles had sent reinforcements

The surrounding countryside had been stripped of supplies

Most critically: The Infantes themselves weren't there

They had withdrawn to separate locations - Infante Juan to his wife's estates near the Navarrese border, Infante Enrique to fortified positions in the north. They'd divided their forces, making simultaneous arrest impossible.

When Álvaro demanded entry to Arévalo, the garrison commander (loyal to the Infantes) responded: "This fortress is held in the name of stability and proper governance. We await the King's personal command, not the orders of his over-mighty subject."

The Standoff

Álvaro faced an impossible choice:

Assault Arévalo: Would succeed but with heavy casualties, and the Infantes weren't even there

Pursue the Infantes separately: Would divide his forces dangerously

Maintain siege: Would tie down troops needed elsewhere

Withdraw: Would look weak but preserve forces

After three days of tense standoff, Álvaro withdrew to Valladolid. He'd successfully avoided bloodshed but failed to arrest the Infantes.

September Developments in Castile

The Noble Response (September 11-20)

The failed arrest attempt had immediate consequences:

Those Supporting the Crown (30-35%) rallied more firmly to Álvaro:

"The Infantes are proven traitors refusing royal justice"

Several offered troops if needed

Cities like Burgos and Toledo explicitly banned the Infantes from entering

The Neutral Majority (50-55%) grew more nervous:

Many withdrew to their estates to wait

Some began fortifying their own positions

Letters flew between noble houses discussing contingencies

Common question: "Is the King truly in command, or has Álvaro seized power?"

The Infantes' Supporters (15-20%) grew bolder:

Claimed this proved Álvaro was tyrant using king's name

Some began mustering their own forces

Master of Santiago (Luis de Guzmán) publicly questioned the arrest order's legitimacy

Letters from Aragon (September 15)

King Alfonso V, from Naples, sent formal protest:

"To our beloved cousin Juan of Castile (when this reaches him) and to Don Álvaro de Luna who currently governs: We are gravely concerned by reports of attempts to arrest our brothers without proper trial or evidence. Such actions against princes of Aragon constitute hostile acts. We trust cooler heads will prevail and this matter will be resolved when Our cousin returns to exercise personal judgment."

The threat was clear: arrest the Infantes and risk war with Aragon.

The Church's Position (September 18)

The Archbishop of Toledo, technically part of the regency council, issued a carefully worded statement:

"The Church counsels patience and reconciliation. These matters should await His Majesty's return. We pray all parties will refrain from actions that might spill Christian blood."

Translation: The Church wouldn't support civil war over this.

Intelligence Reports (September 20-25)

Juan de Daza and Diego Gómez de Sandoval gathered disturbing intelligence:

The Infantes' Network:

They'd known the arrest order was coming (source unknown)

They'd prepared safe houses and escape routes

They were actively recruiting more nobles with promises of positions once "proper governance" was restored

They'd sent agents to Granada suggesting Castile was too divided to launch any crusade

Economic Impact:

Trade disrupted by uncertainty

Some merchants withdrawing funds from royal banks

Tax collection down 15% as collectors feared entering disputed areas

Military expenses mounting with troops on alert

Popular Sentiment:

Common people confused and frightened

Rumors wild: "The King is dead," "The King has become a monk," "Álvaro has imprisoned the King"

Some villages preparing for war

Others just want to harvest crops in peace

Álvaro's Holding Action (September 25-28)

By late September, Álvaro had achieved a tense stability:

What He Managed:

Prevented open civil war

Kept major cities loyal

Maintained government functions

Protected royal revenues (mostly)

Avoided giving Infantes martyrdom through bloodshed

What He Failed to Do:

Arrest the Infantes as ordered

Prevent them from strengthening position

Stop erosion of royal authority

Quiet growing doubts about the King's status

His Message to Juan (sent September 26, will reach Seville soon after Juan):

"Your Majesty,

Your orders regarding the Infantes have been received and acted upon. They refused summons to trial and have withdrawn to fortified positions. Attempted arrest would require military campaign resulting in significant bloodshed.

The realm holds, but tensions mount daily. Your personal presence is urgently needed. Some question whether you truly issued these orders or whether I act independently. Others spread rumors you've died or abdicated.

I've preserved your authority and prevented open warfare, but cannot maintain this balance indefinitely. The Infantes grow bolder, neutrals grow fearful, and even loyalists grow doubtful.

Come swiftly. Show yourself to your people. Whatever you achieved in Rome, we need you here now.

Your servant,
Álvaro de Luna"

The Situation Awaiting Juan (Late September 1430)

When Juan arrives in Seville (which you haven't reached yet), he will find:

The Good News:

No civil war has erupted

Major cities remain loyal

Government still functions

His core supporters held firm

The Infantes exposed as refusing royal justice

The Bad News:

The Infantes remain free and defiant

They've strengthened their position

Noble neutrality hardening into fear

Royal authority questioned

Aragon threatening intervention

Rumors about the King running wild

Economic disruption beginning

Granada watching Castilian weakness

The Immediate Challenges:

Must show himself publicly to dispel rumors

Must decide whether to pursue arrests or seek reconciliation

Must convince nobles the crusade is still viable

Must respond to Alfonso V's threat

Must restore confidence in royal authority

Must prevent Infantes from sabotaging November 8 council

The Hidden Danger (unknown to Juan):
The Infantes knew the arrest was coming because they've been reading his letters. They're prepared for his every move. This intelligence advantage remains their secret weapon.

Captain Fernán awaits in Valladolid, ready to ride south when summoned. Álvaro holds the center but watches the edges crumble. The Infantes plot their next move from their fortresses.

The kingdom holds its breath, waiting for its young king to return from his holy journey and face the crisis his absence—and his orders—have created.

events.summary: In Barcelona, Juan discusses Castilian and Aragonese succession with his companions. He writes a poem expressing spiritual love for Isabel Ruiz, but when María challenges him — pointing out that burdening Isabel with knowledge of impossible love would be selfish — Juan burns the poem. He embraces María and weeps, genuinely letting go of his feelings for the first time. This marks his first real sacrifice of personal desire for another's wellbeing.

exchanges.text:
I am in Barcelona still. I have made plans to finish training and equipping my crusaders and we want to get transport to Sevilla.


Before we leave, I do want to know who would inherit the throne if the current king and his brothers and their children are dead. Out of interest, who would then inherit the throne?

Juan II of Castile in 1430 (we've aged him down to 18 for the game):
- Historically, Juan II was born in 1405 and died in 1454
- His father was Henry III of Castile (died 1406)
- His mother was Catherine of Lancaster

Juan II's siblings:
- María of Castile (his sister, married to Alfonso V of Aragon) - in our game she's in Barcelona
- Catherine of Castile (another sister, married to Infante Henry, Duke of Villena)

So if Juan II died without children, and his siblings died without children, who would inherit?

We need to go back up the family tree to Henry III's siblings or further back to John I of Castile (Juan II's grandfather).

Henry III's siblings:
- Ferdinand I of Aragon (born 1380, died 1416) - He was actually Henry III's brother! He became King of Aragon through the Compromise of Caspe in 1412.

Wait, this is important - Ferdinand I of Aragon was actually a Castilian prince (Infante) before becoming King of Aragon. He was the younger brother of Henry III of Castile.

So the Infantes de Aragón (Juan and Enrique) who are causing problems in our story are actually Juan II's first cousins - they're the sons of Ferdinand I of Aragon, who was Henry III's brother.

So the line of succession if Juan II and his sisters died without heirs would actually potentially go to... the Infantes de Aragón themselves, as they're the male-line descendants of the Trastámara dynasty through Ferdinand I.

But let me think more carefully:

The Trastámara line:
- Henry II of Castile (first Trastámara king)

- John I of Castile (his son)
- Henry III of Castile (John I's son)
- Juan II of Castile (Henry III's son)

I see the family's complex succession involves multiple branches. John I had two key sons: Henry III (Juan II's direct line) and Ferdinand "of Antequera" (who became the Aragonese royal line). If Juan II's direct descendants perished, the crown would likely pass to Ferdinand's descendants - the Aragonese royal family. However, potential alternative claimants might exist through female lineages or other familial branches.

Potential succession paths reveal intricate political dynamics. Female-line connections through Portuguese royal marriages could introduce additional claims. The hierarchy of succession appears nuanced: first Juan II's potential children, then his sisters' potential offspring, followed by the Aragonese line and possibly Portuguese royalty through female descent. These complex inheritance possibilities represent politically sensitive information that could dramatically impact royal power struggles.

Looking at the question of Castilian succession, you consider the dynastic implications - a king should know these matters well.

The Line of Succession from Juan II of Castile (1430)

Your Immediate Line:

You (Juan II, age 18, no children yet)

Your sister María (Queen of Aragon, age 33, married to Alfonso V but childless after 15 years of marriage)

Your sister Catherine (died in 1424, was married to Infante Henry, Duke of Villena - no surviving children)

The Uncomfortable Truth:

If you and María die without heirs, the succession becomes complicated and extremely uncomfortable:

The next legitimate male-line heirs would be... the Infantes de Aragón themselves.

Here's why: Your grandfather, John I of Castile, had two sons:

Henry III (your father, died 1406)

Ferdinand "of Antequera" (who became Ferdinand I of Aragon in 1412)

Ferdinand I's sons are:

Alfonso V (current King of Aragon, married to your sister)

Infante Juan (King of Navarre, the one you just tried to arrest)

Infante Enrique (the other one you tried to arrest)

Infante Pedro (died 1438)

Infante Sancho (Master of Alcántara)

So the very men who just rebelled against you are actually your father's first cousins and stand in the line of succession. If you died without heirs, Castile might legally pass to:

Alfonso V of Aragon (as eldest son of Ferdinand I)

Infante Juan of Navarre

Infante Enrique

Their younger brothers

The Political Explosion:

This means:

The Infantes aren't just rebellious nobles - they have royal blood and distant succession rights

Some nobles might see them as legitimate alternatives if you die young

Your arrest attempt could be seen as trying to eliminate rival claimants

Alfonso V could potentially inherit both Castile and Aragon, uniting the crowns

This gives the Infantes a "legitimate" grievance - you tried to arrest potential heirs to the throne

Other Possible Claimants:

Through female lines, there might be claims from:

Portuguese royalty (through various Castilian-Portuguese marriages)

Descendants of John of Gaunt (through your grandmother Catherine of Lancaster)

Other Trastámara female-line descendants

But the strongest claim would be the Aragonese line.

Your Strategic Vulnerability:

As you stand in your Barcelona chambers considering this, the full weight hits you:

You're 18 with no wife or children

You're about to embark on a dangerous crusade

The men with the best claim to succeed you are the ones you just tried to arrest

Every month you remain unmarried and childless strengthens their position

If you die in battle against Granada, Castile likely becomes part of Aragon

Fray Hernando, if consulted, might observe: "Perhaps God preserved you from your feelings for Isabel for a reason. You need a political marriage that produces heirs quickly. Every day without an heir is a day the Infantes grow stronger."

This knowledge makes your upcoming confrontation with the Infantes even more delicate. They know what you now fully realize - they're not just nobles to be arrested. They're potential kings of Castile.

What do you wish to do with this uncomfortable realization?
And how is the situation for the throne of Aragon? What happens if the infantes and king Alfonso die without heirs? Just purely hypothetical?

Alfonso V of Aragon (born 1396, so age 34 in 1430) is married to María of Castile (Juan's sister) but they have no children after 15 years of marriage. Historically, Alfonso V died without legitimate children.

The succession for the Crown of Aragon if Alfonso V and his brothers all died without heirs:

1. Alfonso V - no children despite being married since 1415
2. Infante Juan of Navarre - has a son, Carlos, Prince of Viana (age 9 in 1430)
3. Infante Enrique - might have children?
4. Infante Sancho - Master of Alcántara
5. Infante Pedro - died historically in 1438

Wait, I established in the story that Infante Juan has a son, Carlos (age 9), the Prince of Viana. So if we're talking about all of them dying without heirs, we need to go further back.

If the entire male line of Ferdinand I of Aragon dies out, we need to look at:
- Female lines from Ferdinand I
- Going back to earlier Aragonese succession

Actually, this gets very complex. The Crown of Aragon had different succession laws than Castile. Let me think about what Juan would realistically know and what would happen.

If all of Ferdinand I's sons and grandsons died, the succession would be extremely disputed. There would be:
- Female-line descendants of Ferdinand I
- Claims from other branches of the House of Barcelona/Aragon
- Possibly claims from Castile through María (Juan's sister, Alfonso's wife)
- Claims from other royal houses

This is getting very hypothetical and Juan is clearly thinking about something here...

You lean back in your chair, mind racing through the dynastic implications. A hypothetical question, but kings must think in hypotheticals.

The Aragonese Succession Question

Current Line of Succession for Aragon:

Alfonso V (age 34, childless after 15 years of marriage to your sister María)

Infante Juan of Navarre (has a son: Carlos, Prince of Viana, age 9)

Infante Enrique (no legitimate children known)

Infante Sancho (Master of Alcántara, no children)

Infante Pedro (still alive, no significant offspring)

So currently, if Alfonso V dies, the crown passes to Infante Juan, then to young Carlos of Viana.

But If They All Died Without Heirs...

The succession becomes incredibly murky. Ferdinand I (their father) took the Aragonese throne through the Compromise of Caspe in 1412, but he was himself a Castilian prince. If his entire line fails...

Potential Claimants Would Include:

Your sister María - As Alfonso V's widow, she might claim the throne in her own right (Aragon has had ruling queens before, like Petronilla)

You yourself - Through your sister's marriage and as grandson of Catherine of Lancaster, you'd have a claim

The House of Urgell - They contested Ferdinand I's succession in 1412. James II, Count of Urgell, fought a war over it. His descendants might revive their claim.

Various Catalan noble houses - Who trace descent from earlier kings of Aragon

Even France might assert some ancient claim through old marriages

The Strategic Implications:

As this thought experiment unfolds in your mind, several realizations dawn:

If the male Aragonese line died out:

Your sister María could potentially become Queen of Aragon in her own right

You could press a claim through her

Castile and Aragon might unite under your house, not theirs

The Crown of Aragon includes Naples, Sicily, Sardinia, Valencia, Catalonia - vast territories

The Uncomfortable Mirror:

Just as the Infantes stand to inherit Castile if you die without heirs...

You could potentially inherit Aragon if they all died without heirs

Both kingdoms' successions are precariously intertwined

Both sides have incentive to ensure the other doesn't produce heirs

Why This Matters Now:

Sir Thomas, if present, might observe: "Your Majesty, purely hypothetically... if something happened to all the Aragonese princes during, say, a dangerous military campaign like a crusade, and your sister survived as Alfonso's widow..."

Fray Hernando would immediately interject: "That line of thinking leads to dark places, Your Majesty."

But the political reality is clear:

The Infantes aren't just your rivals - they're blocking your potential inheritance of Aragon

You're not just their rival - you're blocking their potential inheritance of Castile

Your sister María sits at the center of both succession questions

Every major noble in both kingdoms knows this

The Current Wild Card:

Young Carlos, Prince of Viana (age 9) - Infante Juan's son. He's the only child in the next generation on either side. If he survives to adulthood, he could inherit:

Navarre (from his father)

Potentially Aragon (if Alfonso dies childless)

Potentially Castile (if you die childless)

Unless you have children. Soon.

The Dangerous Game:

This succession tangle means:

Every military campaign carries dynastic implications

Every marriage negotiation affects both kingdoms

Every feast, every hunt, every voyage risks changing everything

The Infantes' rebellion wasn't just about power - it was about positioning for potential inheritance

Your arrest order looked like trying to eliminate rival heirs

As you consider this in Barcelona - in Alfonso V's own city, surrounded by Aragonese nobles who all understand these implications - you realize everyone is watching you very, very carefully.

"Purely hypothetical," you might say aloud. But Diego, your secretary, would know to burn any papers with these calculations. Some hypotheticals are too dangerous to commit to writing.

What would you like to do with these dynastic insights?

I wrap up my time in Barcelona and before we leave I write a poem I give to my sister.


Sister, I have written this poem about my feeling for Isabel. I entrust it to you to read and keep. I do not want to burden Isabel with my love for her, but if you deem it appropriate, you can show her this poem. You know the truth of my heart and why I wrote it. I now entrust it to you.


Like the stars she is bright
Like the moon she is light
I try to reach for her, knowing I can never hold such beauty. 
For how can we hold God's grace in our hand? 
When can we capture love to keep close to us?


We can not, we can only set them free. 
Let them shine like stars for when they do they will shine all the brighter. 
I place my love for you in God's kingdom where is is forever pure. 
I do not fear the next world for it will bring me closer to my love for you. 
My bright star.


I let her read it.

María takes the parchment carefully, her eyes moving across your handwritten words. As she reads, her expression shifts from curiosity to deep sadness. When she finishes, she holds the poem against her chest for a moment, eyes glistening.

"Oh, Juan..." she whispers. "My dear little brother."

She reads it again, more slowly this time, and you see her lips move slightly over the words I place my love for you in God's kingdom where it is forever pure.

"It's beautiful," she says finally, her voice thick with emotion. "And heartbreaking. You've captured something I felt once but could never put into words." She looks up at you. "That feeling of loving someone you cannot have, of trying to transform earthly desire into something spiritual and eternal."

She carefully folds the parchment. "You say you don't want to burden her with your love, yet you write 'my love for you' - addressing her directly. Part of you does want her to know, doesn't it?"

María moves to her writing desk, opens a small wooden box with a key from around her neck, and places your poem inside. "I'll keep it safe. As for showing it to her..." She pauses, considering. "That's a heavy responsibility you've given me. To judge whether this would heal or harm."

She turns back to you. "Isabel is... unusual. Since the tea, she's been quieter than normal. Her mother says she's been reading that book of poetry you gave her constantly. She asked me once, very carefully, whether you were well. When I said you were busy with crusade preparations, she just nodded and changed the subject."

"I think she understands more than you know. Young women often do." María touches your cheek gently. "I'll watch her. If I believe seeing this would bring her peace rather than pain, if I think it would help her understand rather than torture her with what cannot be... then perhaps. But not now. Not when you're leaving. That would be cruel."

She embraces you tightly. "You're doing a brave thing, hermano. Letting her go. Letting her live her life unburdened by the love of a king who cannot choose her. But this poem... it shows your heart hasn't let go. Maybe it never will."

Drawing back, she asks quietly, "Do you want my honest opinion? Not as your sister, but as a woman who understands something of impossible love?"

How do you respond?
I would like nothing more sister

Juan is asking for María's honest opinion about his poem and his feelings for Isabel. This is a tender moment between siblings where María can give him her genuine perspective as a woman who has experienced similar heartbreak.

María takes a breath, choosing her words carefully.

"The poem is beautiful, Juan. But it's also... selfish." She holds up her hand before you can protest. "Not intentionally. But look at what you've written. You speak of setting her free, yet you write directly to her - 'my love for you.' You say you place your love in God's kingdom where it's pure, but you also say you don't fear death because it will bring you closer to your love for her."

She sits down, gesturing for you to sit beside her. "You're trying to have it both ways, hermano. You want to nobly release her while also declaring eternal, spiritual love. You want her to be free while also being forever yours in some heavenly realm."

María's voice grows gentler. "I understand the impulse. When I lost my young knight, I told myself similar things. That our love existed somewhere pure and eternal, untouchable by politics or duty. It was the only way I could bear it."

She takes your hand. "But here's what I learned: That kind of thinking is a beautiful prison. For both of you. You're not truly letting her go - you're transforming your love into something she can never escape, even if she wanted to. If she sees this poem, she'll carry it forever. Every time she looks at stars, she'll think of being your 'bright star.' Every prayer, she'll wonder about that pure love in God's kingdom waiting for her."

María squeezes your hand. "Is that kind? Is that the mercy you spoke of in your crusade oaths? Or is it asking her to be forever haunted by a love that exists only in poetry and heaven?"

She stands and walks to the window overlooking Barcelona. "You want my honest opinion? If you truly love her, let her forget you. Let her meet someone who can actually hold her hand, marry her, give her children and a real life. Don't transform her into an eternal symbol of impossible love."

Turning back to you, her expression is sympathetic but firm. "The poem is beautiful, Juan. Your feelings are real and profound. But sometimes the greatest act of love is to leave no trace of it at all. To let the other person be completely, truly free."

She returns to the wooden box. "I'll keep the poem. But I don't think I'll ever show it to her. Not because it isn't beautiful, but because it is. Because she deserves the chance to heal and move on without the weight of being forever your 'bright star' - close enough to see but too far to touch."

María embraces you again. "I'm sorry if that's not what you wanted to hear. But you asked for honesty from someone who understands impossible love. This is what I've learned: The kindest thing is often the hardest - to love someone enough to let them forget you entirely."

She pulls back to look at your face. "Can you do that, Juan? Can you love her enough to hope she forgets you?"

I am not selfish if I can help it.


I grab the poem and tight it on fire.


Isabel has hurt me more than everything else in this world sister. And I will not burden anyone with this if I can help it.


I watch the poem burn down and hold my sister close and let my tears fall.

María holds you tightly as the parchment curls into ash in the fireplace, the words disappearing into smoke. She feels your body shake with tears and pulls you closer, cradling your head against her shoulder as she did when you were a small child - those few precious times before she left for Barcelona.

"Oh, mi querido hermano," she murmurs, her own tears falling into your hair. "I know. I know how much it hurts."

She doesn't try to stop your tears or offer empty comfort. She just holds you, letting you grieve for the love you're truly letting go. The ashes settle in the grate - no trace left of your beautiful, dangerous words.

"The pain means it was real," she whispers after a long moment. "And burning the poem... Juan, that was the most unselfish thing you could have done. You're not just letting her go in words now, but in truth."

She rocks you slightly, as mothers do with hurt children. "She hasn't hurt you by any cruelty, has she? She's hurt you simply by existing, by being someone you cannot have. That's the sharpest pain there is - when no one is to blame but fate itself."

María pulls back enough to wipe your tears with her sleeve, not caring that it stains the fine fabric. "You're so young to learn this lesson. But you're learning it with such grace. Father would be proud of the man you're becoming - not the king with the crusade and the glory, but this man who can burn a love poem to spare a girl's heart."

She cups your face in her hands. "The hurt will fade, hermano. Not quickly, not completely, but it will become bearable. One day you'll be able to think of her green eyes without this sharp pain. One day you might even be grateful for having felt something so profound, even if you couldn't keep it."

"But today, you're allowed to grieve. Here, with me, where no one else can see. Let it out, all of it."

She holds you close again. "And know this - Isabel may have hurt you without meaning to, but you've chosen not to hurt her in return. That's not the choice of a selfish boy. That's the choice of a good man. A true king."

The ashes are completely cold now, nothing but gray dust that could have been anything - a letter, a ledger, a love poem that will never be read.

"When you're ready," María says softly, "we'll wash your face, and you'll go to your ships, and you'll sail to Seville. And no one will know about this moment except us. Your strength and your tears - both will be our secret."

events.summary: Juan departs Barcelona with three galleys (Santa Eulalia, Sant Jordi, Mare de Déu) carrying 62 crusaders, relics, banner, and treasury. Success roll — the 10-day voyage includes several tense moments: bluffing past Valencia's inspection with threats of excommunication, a corsair encounter where pirates retreat upon seeing the armed formation, and Moroccan war galleys shadowing them through the Strait of Gibraltar. All arrive safely in Seville on September 28.

exchanges.text:
I return to m,y crusade and board the ships. We sail for Sevilla.


Consider this an action. How likely are we to succeed? We intend to make good time, but considering our precious cargo, we want this secured above all else.

Factors in favor:
- Three ships provide security in numbers
- Ships can defend each other
- September is generally good sailing weather in the Mediterranean
- The crew and captains are presumably experienced
- Juan has adequate guards for the relics
- The western Mediterranean route to Seville is well-traveled
- Hiring three ships shows good planning

Potential obstacles:
- Granada has been building naval forces (20-25 war galleys from Muslim support)
- Corsairs and pirates are always a risk
- The Infantes' agents might have sent word ahead
- Weather can always turn bad
- Three ships traveling together are more noticeable than one
- The valuable cargo makes them a prime target if identified
- Sailing around through the Strait of Gibraltar has its own risks

However, the documents don't indicate that Granada's navy is actively patrolling this far north yet, and there's no indication they know Juan's specific travel plans. The journey from Barcelona to Seville, while requiring passage through the Strait of Gibraltar, is a regular trade route.

Given the planning, multiple ships, and the fact that this is a relatively routine voyage (though with precious cargo), I'd say this is "Likely to succeed" - not guaranteed, but the precautions taken should be sufficient for a safe journey under normal circumstances.

Looking at your planned voyage from Barcelona to Seville with three ships, let me assess the probability of success.

Probability Assessment: Likely to succeed

Factors in Your Favor:

Strong Security Measures:

Three ships traveling together - mutual defense capability

62 trained crusaders plus experienced guards

Rodrigo, García, Sir Thomas commanding security

Four dedicated guards on permanent rotation for the relics

Ships can support each other if one has trouble

Good Timing & Conditions:

Mid-September: generally favorable sailing weather in the Western Mediterranean

Well-traveled trade route from Barcelona around to Seville

Experienced Catalan captains who know these waters

The grape harvest season means heavy merchant traffic to blend with

Element of Discretion:

While three ships are noticeable, they're not flying royal banners

Could appear as normal merchant convoy

Granada's naval forces likely concentrated near their own waters

No indication your specific departure date is known to enemies

Potential Dangers:

Maritime Risks:

The Strait of Gibraltar is always dangerous - currents, winds, and narrow passage

Corsair activity possible, especially North African raiders

September can bring sudden storms in the Mediterranean

Three ships must stay together, slowing to pace of slowest vessel

Enemy Intelligence:

The Infantes know you're in Barcelona (their agents watched)

Granada has 20-25 war galleys from Muslim allies

Your valuable cargo would be an incredible prize if identified

Some pirates might take three ships as challenge rather than deterrent

Political Complications:

Must pass through waters near Granada's influence

Aragonese ships might be tracking your departure

News travels fast along the coast

Assessment:

Your precautions are sound. Three ships with trained fighters and experienced guards should handle normal maritime threats. The route, while long, is regularly traveled. Your security measures for the relics are excellent. The main vulnerabilities are the Strait of Gibraltar passage and the possibility of concentrated enemy action if your identity is discovered.

However, unless you encounter a major Granada naval squadron or severe weather, your force should reach Seville successfully.

Please roll your dice to determine the outcome of your voyage.

Result is success.


Describe our journey using this result.

The Voyage to Seville

September 18-28, 1430

Departure from Barcelona (September 18, Dawn)

The three galleys waited at Barcelona's main quay as morning mist rolled off the Mediterranean. You'd hired experienced Catalan captains:

Santa Eulalia (flagship) - Captain Ramon Berenguer, 40 oars

Sant Jordi - Captain Pere Marquet, 35 oars

Mare de Déu - Captain Arnau Sabater, 35 oars

Your crusaders boarded in good order. The weeks of training showed - they moved like soldiers now, not the ragged volunteers who'd arrived. Their white tabards with red crosses caught the early sunlight.

María came to see you off, accompanied by several nobles from the Consell Reial. She embraced you formally, then whispered: "The ashes are gone, hermano. Let the wind take the rest of your grief."

As the Santa Eulalia pulled away from the quay, you stood at the stern watching Barcelona recede. Somewhere in that city, Isabel was probably just waking. You turned your face to the sea.

The First Days (September 18-20)

The three ships maintained close formation, never more than a quarter-mile apart. Captain Berenguer proved excellent - he'd clearly managed convoy escort before.

Your crusaders adapted to shipboard life with varying success. The former mercenary Marco barely noticed the ship's roll. Pietro vomited for two days straight but kept trying to stand watch. Brother Guillem led prayers at dawn and dusk, his clear voice carrying across the water to the other ships.

On the second evening, Captain Berenguer pointed to distant sails. "Fishing boats, Your Majesty. But see how they're not actually fishing? They're watching. By tomorrow, every port from here to Valencia will know three ships passed south in formation."

"Is that a problem?"

"Not necessarily. But we're not invisible."

The Challenge at Valencia (September 21)

Valencia's harbor authorities tried to insist you anchor for "inspection." Three war galleys emerged to encourage compliance.

Captain Berenguer looked to you. "We can outrun them, but it would confirm we're carrying something valuable. Or we can bluff."

You chose to bluff. Standing visible on deck in your white garments (but not displaying the banner), you had Berenguer signal: "Crusaders bound for Seville under papal authority. Interference with holy mission carries excommunication."

The Valencian galleys held position for a tense hour. Your crusaders lined the rails, hands on weapons but not drawn. Finally, the Valencian commander signaled: "Pass in peace. God speed your holy work."

As Valencia fell behind, Sir Thomas observed: "That commander will still report three ships of crusaders heading south. Word will reach Granada before we do."

The Corsair Encounter (September 23)

Off the coast near Cartagena, two sleek vessels emerged from a hidden cove - Barbary corsairs, swift and predatory. They'd clearly been tracking you since dawn.

"They're testing us," Captain Berenguer said. "Seeing if we'll scatter."

The corsairs swept closer, within crossbow range. You could see their crews - a mix of Berbers, renegade Christians, and sub-Saharan Africans. Professional pirates.

You made a decision. "Unfurl the banner. Let them see what they're considering attacking."

When the white silk unfurled with the golden reliquary of the True Cross gleaming in the sunlight, an extraordinary thing happened. Several of the corsair crew visibly stepped back. You heard arguing on their deck. Their captain - a gray-bearded Berber - stood at his bow staring at the banner for a long moment.

Then he raised his hand in what might have been salute or acknowledgment, and both corsair vessels sheared off, disappearing southward.

Fray Hernando murmured: "Even pirates fear God sometimes. Or perhaps they fear the consequences of attacking a ship bearing the True Cross."

"Or," Rodrigo added pragmatically, "they decided three ships full of armed crusaders wasn't worth the cost."

The Strait of Gibraltar (September 25)

The most dangerous part of your voyage. The narrow passage between Christendom and Islam, where Atlantic meets Mediterranean, where currents can smash ships against rocks and where Granada's allies waited.

Five Moroccan war galleys patrolled the southern approach.

Captain Berenguer gathered the three captains. "We can wait for night, try to slip through in darkness. Or we run the strait in daylight, counting on speed and formation."

You chose daylight. "We're not smugglers. We're crusaders under papal authority."

The run through the strait was harrowing. The Moroccan galleys shadowed you the entire way, maintaining perfect position to intercept if you tried to land on the African coast. Your crusaders stood to arms for six straight hours. The banner remained visible, relics gleaming.

At the narrowest point, one Moroccan galley surged forward as if to ram, then veered off at the last moment - a test of nerve. Your formation held.

As you entered the Atlantic, the Moroccan squadron fell back. They'd delivered their message: We're watching. We're ready.

The Atlantic Coast (September 26-27)

The weather turned rough as you sailed north along the Atlantic coast toward Seville. Not a full storm, but heavy seas that had your landlubber crusaders groaning in misery.

Pietro, green-faced but determined, asked: "Your Majesty, how do you stand it?"

"I think about where we're going," you replied. "Each wave brings us closer to Seville. Closer to the Council. Closer to beginning God's work."

During the worst of the weather, you found Giovanni the blacksmith at the rail, not seasick but praying steadily. "For safe voyage?" you asked.

"No, Your Majesty. Thanking God for the storm."

"Why?"

"Because if He sends storms, it means He's watching. He hasn't forgotten us."

Simple faith, but it moved you.

Arrival at Seville (September 28, Afternoon)

The Guadalquivir River's mouth appeared through morning haze. Your three ships turned upriver, oars beating steadily against the current.

As you approached Seville, the city's bells began ringing - not alarm, but welcome. Word had preceded you. Crowds gathered along the riverbanks. Your crusaders stood straighter, white tabards bright despite the voyage.

Then you saw him: Álvaro de Luna waited at the main dock with a small honor guard. His face was carefully composed, but you knew him well enough to see the relief.

As the Santa Eulalia tied up, Álvaro called out: "Your Majesty! Thanks be to God for your safe return."

You stepped onto the dock - Castilian soil after five months away. Álvaro dropped to one knee formally, then rose and embraced you, whispering urgently: "We must talk immediately. The Infantes refused arrest. They're fortified and defiant. The realm holds, but barely. And there's more - Granada's embassy arrived three days ago. They're waiting to see you."

Behind Álvaro, you noticed several richly dressed Moors watching from a balcony. The Granadan delegation, studying their future opponent.

You nodded to Álvaro but kept your voice carrying: "We have returned with God's blessing and the Pope's commission. Let all of Seville know - the King is home, and the crusade shall begin!"

The crowd erupted in cheers. Your 62 crusaders disembarked in formation, their disciplined appearance causing murmurs of approval. When Rodrigo and García brought the banner-chest containing the relics, people dropped to their knees.

But even as you waved to the crowd, Álvaro's urgent expression told you everything: You'd returned not to a united kingdom ready for crusade, but to a realm on the edge of civil war.

Your successful voyage is complete. You've arrived in Seville with:

All 62 crusaders safe and accounted for

The sacred relics and papal bull secure

Your military equipment and treasury intact

Your reputation enhanced by the disciplined arrival

Five weeks until the November 8 Royal Council

But the challenges awaiting you are severe:

The Infantes remain free and defiant

Granada's embassy is here with an offer

The nobility questions your authority

Civil war threatens

What is your first action upon landing in Seville?

events.summary: In the Torre del Oro, Álvaro briefs Juan on the state of the kingdom: the papal bull is legend (half of Castile thinks Juan a living saint), but the Infantes refused arrest and control ~5,000 troops with 8 noble houses. About 30% of nobility supports the crown, 20% the Infantes, 50% neutral. Juan discusses options including execution — Álvaro warns this would mean war with Aragon and horror among European courts. They agree to focus on stabilizing the realm first, confirming arrest orders publicly, and dealing with the Granadan delegation.

exchanges.text:
Lets talk Alvaro, my friend. Send a message to the Grenada delegation that I welcome them and will meet that soon.


Lets strategize Alvaro. Lets get somewhere where we are safe.

Juan has just arrived in Seville and wants to speak with Álvaro de Luna privately first before dealing with the Granada delegation. This makes sense - he needs to understand the full situation before making any diplomatic moves. He's being cautious about security too, wanting a safe location for the discussion.

Let me describe Álvaro taking Juan to a secure location and briefing him on the situation in detail.

Álvaro nods sharply, immediately understanding. "Diego," he calls to your secretary, "Send word to the Granadan delegation that His Majesty acknowledges their presence and will grant them audience once he has attended to urgent matters of state. They've waited three days; a few more hours won't matter."

He turns to Rodrigo. "Captain, secure the relics in the cathedral treasury. Four guards at all times. Nobody touches them without His Majesty's direct presence."

"Sir Thomas," Álvaro continues, "see to quartering the crusaders. The Alcázar's outer barracks are prepared."

Then quietly to you: "Come. We'll go to the Torre del Oro. It's secure, and we won't be overheard."

The Torre del Oro - Secure Conference

The Tower of Gold, Seville's famous defensive tower by the river, has a chamber at its top used for the most sensitive discussions. Álvaro has posted his most trusted men at every level. Only the two of you stand in the circular room, windows showing the Guadalquivir below.

Álvaro pours wine from a flask he brought himself - taking no chances with poison. His face, now that you're alone, shows the strain of the past months.

"Juan," he says, dropping formality. "Thank God you're back. First, the good - you should know what you achieved. The papal bull is already legend. Cardinal Orsini wrote to the Archbishop of Toledo describing your... presentation to the Pope. The story has spread everywhere. Half of Castile thinks you're a living saint. The other half thinks you're mad, but even they're impressed by the audacity."

He drinks deeply. "Now the bad. The Infantes didn't just refuse arrest - they've been actively building a coalition against you. They claim the arrest order was forged by me, that you're either dead, imprisoned, or lost in religious mania. About eight noble houses believe them. Another thirty are waiting to see proof you're actually in command."

Álvaro moves to a map on the table. "Here's where we stand militarily." He points to various positions:

"The Infantes control:

Arévalo fortress

Two minor castles here and here

Their own estates, heavily fortified

About 5,000 troops total

Master of Santiago supports them with another 2,000

We control:

All major cities

The royal administration

About 3,000 royal troops

The loyalty of about 15-20 noble houses who could raise maybe 8,000 more

Masters of Calatrava and Alcántara remain neutral but lean toward us

The problem: If we move against the Infantes militarily, it's civil war. Alfonso V has already threatened to intervene from Aragon if his brothers are harmed. We'd win eventually, but the cost..."

He pauses, then adds grimly: "And that's before we consider Granada. Juan, their delegation isn't just here to negotiate. They arrived with disturbing news. The Sultan has received massive support from across the Muslim world - Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, even the Ottomans. They have gold, troops, and ships we didn't expect. Our spies report at least 20,000 troops gathering in Granada, with modern Ottoman cannon."

Álvaro refills his cup. "The Granadan ambassador, Abu Abdullah al-Zaghal, is clever. He's been very visible in Seville, visiting churches, speaking with merchants, being conspicuously peaceful. He's brought gifts worth a fortune. The message is clear: Granada wants peace and is strong enough to enforce it."

He looks at you directly. "The November 8 Council is ten days away. Every major noble will attend - including the Infantes, who claim they're coming to 'protect the realm from false orders.' If you appear weak, if the kingdom looks divided, the crusade dies before it begins. Worse, we might face civil war."

"But," Álvaro adds with a slight smile, "you have advantages they don't expect. The papal bull is real and spectacular. The True Cross and Santiago's bone - nobody can argue with those. Your 62 crusaders made an impression arriving in formation. And most importantly, you're here, alive, clearly in command. That alone destroys half the Infantes' arguments."

He leans against the window. "So, my king, my friend - what's our strategy? Do we:

Try to reconcile with the Infantes before the Council? Offer them something to stand down?

Prepare for confrontation at the Council? Use the papal authority to override their political maneuvering?

Deal with Granada first? If we could secure peace or alliance there, it would free us to handle the Infantes?

Something else entirely?

The realm needs you to be brilliant, Juan. What the Pope gave you is powerful, but it's not enough by itself. How do we turn this situation to our advantage?"

Álvaro waits, watching you with the keen intelligence that has kept him alive through decades of court intrigue. Below, the Guadalquivir flows toward the sea, and somewhere in the city, Granadan diplomats and the Infantes' agents are making their own plans.

What is your strategic decision?

You have done right ALvaro. Good you have prevented bloodshed.


Is it known in the realm that the infantes should have turned themselves in?

Juan is asking whether it's public knowledge that the Infantes were ordered to surrender themselves for trial. This is important for understanding the political situation and how the arrest order has been perceived.

Based on the narrative so far:
- Álvaro made a public summons on September 5th in Valladolid's main square
- Heralds proclaimed that the Infantes were summoned to present themselves to royal justice
- The proclamation was copied and sent to every major city in Castile
- The Infantes publicly responded on September 7th, denying charges and refusing to surrender to Álvaro
- They sent copies of their response to major noble houses, the Archbishop, and Alfonso V

So yes, it's very much public knowledge that they were ordered to surrender and refused.

Álvaro nods grimly. "Oh yes, it's known. I made sure of that. On September 5th, I had heralds proclaim the summons in Valladolid's main square and sent copies to every major city. The charges were explicit - rebellion, seizure of royal property, conspiracy against the crown. They had ten days to surrender themselves peacefully."

He pulls out a document from his pouch. "And here's where they made a mistake. They responded publicly, in writing. Listen to this part: 'We question the legitimacy of orders issued in the King's absence and demand to see His Majesty personally before submitting to any proceedings. We will not surrender ourselves to Don Álvaro de Luna, whom we consider party to this conflict rather than neutral arbiter.'"

Álvaro sets the document down. "They sent copies to every noble house, the Archbishop of Toledo, even Alfonso V in Naples. So yes, everyone knows they were ordered to appear for trial and refused. They've tried to spin it as refusing to submit to me rather than to you, but the fact remains - they defied a royal summons."

He leans forward. "This is actually one of our advantages, Juan. They're in open defiance of royal justice. They can claim the orders were illegitimate, but now you're here. You can confirm the orders were real. That makes them rebels who refused legitimate royal summons. Even their supporters will have difficulty arguing against that."

"The question is how to use this. Some of the neutral nobles are disturbed that the Infantes refused to even appear for trial. As several have said privately - if they were innocent, why not come and defend themselves? Their refusal makes them look guilty, even to those who might sympathize with their complaints about me."

Álvaro's eyes sharpen. "If you publicly confirm at the Council that you personally ordered their arrest, that you stand behind the charges, it puts them in a difficult position. They either submit to trial or confirm themselves as rebels before the entire realm. But it also risks pushing them to desperate action."

"What do you think? Should we use their public refusal against them?"

Can we not just arrest them on sight right now? I mean, it is a lawful order and I can even confirm this right now. But do we not give them more credit and power by not arresting them the moment any servant of the crown meets them?

Juan is making a good point - if the Infantes have been lawfully summoned and refused, and are now declared rebels, why aren't they being arrested on sight? Why would they be allowed to come to the Royal Council? Let me think through the practical and political realities here.

1. The Infantes have military forces - they're not just walking around unprotected. They likely travel with armed retinues.

2. They're princes of Aragon - arresting them could trigger war with Aragon

3. They've claimed they'll come to the Council to "protect the realm" - so they're positioning themselves as coming to participate, not as rebels

4. The practical reality of medieval justice - you need force to arrest someone with their own army

5. The political question - attempting to arrest them at the Council could turn the Council into a battlefield

This is a good strategic question from Juan - why give them legitimacy by letting them attend?

Álvaro's expression shifts - surprise, then consideration, then a slow nod of respect.

"Christ's blood, you're right. Every moment we don't arrest them, we legitimize them." He starts pacing. "If a common lord refused royal summons, we'd have men hunting him across Castile. But the Infantes? We let them move freely, gather support, even come to the Royal Council?"

He stops at the window. "Here's the ugly truth: They have 5,000 troops. When they travel, they move with at least 500 armed men. To arrest them 'on sight' means attacking their escort. That's a battle, not an arrest. Blood in the streets of Seville if they come here."

"But you're raising a crucial point," Álvaro continues, turning back. "If we let them walk into the Royal Council as if they're legitimate participants rather than fugitives from justice... we've already lost. Every noble will see that royal summons can be ignored if you have enough swords."

He thinks intensely. "What if... what if we make the arrest warrant public here in Seville, today? You personally, visibly, confirm the orders. Anyone who aids or shelters them is guilty of harboring rebels. Then:

If they come to the Council, they must come under flag of truce to surrender themselves

If they come armed and defiant, they mark themselves as rebels before everyone

If they don't come, they've abandoned any claim to legitimacy

We could send heralds today to every approaching road: 'The Infantes de Aragón are commanded to surrender themselves to royal justice. Any who enter Seville must do so unarmed and prepared to answer charges.'"

Álvaro's eyes gleam. "It's aggressive. It might provoke them. But you're right - every day we treat them as princes rather than rebels, we weaken royal authority. What do you command?"

Lets do just that. I can adress the nobles in Sevilla if that gives it extra weight.


Also, what would be the punishment if they are indeed judged to be rebellious? What would be their punishment?

For medieval law regarding rebellion/treason by high nobility:
- Death would be the standard punishment for treason/rebellion
- But these are royal princes, brothers of the King of Aragon
- Typically for such high nobility, punishments might include:
  - Execution (rare for royal blood)
  - Exile/banishment
  - Loss of all titles and lands
  - Imprisonment 
  - Forced monastery/religious life
  - Heavy fines

The political reality is that executing them would almost certainly mean war with Aragon. Juan would need to consider this carefully.

Álvaro nods approvingly. "Yes, your personal confirmation would make it undeniable. We'll gather the nobles tonight - most are already here for the Council anyway."

Then his expression turns grave at your second question. "The punishment for rebellion... technically it's death, Juan. Treason against the crown is a capital crime. But..."

He walks to the map again, staring at it. "These aren't ordinary nobles. They're Infantes of Aragon, royal blood. Alfonso V's brothers. If we execute them, it means war with Aragon, possibly Navarre too. No question."

"Historically, when dealing with rebellious royal princes, kings have chosen alternatives:

Exile - Banishment from Castile permanently

Loss of all Castilian titles and lands - Strip them of everything they hold from you

Imprisonment - Usually in comfortable but secure confinement

Forced religious life - Making them take holy orders, enter a monastery

Massive fines - Bankrupt them but leave them alive

Or combinations thereof."

Álvaro turns to you. "If I may be frank? The smartest punishment would be: Strip them of all Castilian lands and titles, exile them permanently, and let them keep their lives and Aragonese holdings. They become Alfonso's problem, not ours. We look merciful but firm."

"But if you want to make an example..." he pauses. "Imprisonment until they publicly swear loyalty and renounce all claims to influence in Castile. Then exile. It shows strength without forcing Alfonso to invade to save his brothers' lives."

"The key is this - whatever you threaten must be something you're willing to actually do. If you threaten death but everyone knows you won't follow through, you look weak. If you threaten exile and they call your bluff, you must be ready to enforce it."

"What sounds right to you? And remember - you don't have to announce the specific punishment now. You can simply confirm they must answer charges of rebellion, and let them wonder what that might mean."

Álvaro adds: "Shall I summon the nobles for this evening? The Archbishop of Toledo is here, along with about forty major lords who've arrived early for the Council. Enough to make it official and public."

The infantes concern me because their existence poses a threat to my rule. Even if I strip them of all their Castillian titles, they may very well inherit the crown of Aragon instead and then I have a powerful enemy in a kingdom that is very close to my own.


Is it possible that we can force them to renounce their Aragonese claims as well?

1. The Infantes are brothers to Alfonso V of Aragon
2. If Alfonso dies childless (which seems likely after 15 years of marriage to Juan's sister María), the crown passes to Infante Juan, then potentially to Infante Enrique
3. Juan cannot force them to renounce Aragonese succession rights - that's entirely outside his jurisdiction as King of Castile
4. This would be like the King of France trying to force an English prince to renounce his rights to the English throne - no legal authority

This is actually a very astute observation from Juan, recognizing the long-term dynastic threat. Álvaro would understand this immediately but also recognize the impossibility.

Álvaro's eyes widen, then he shakes his head slowly. "Christ, you see it too. If Alfonso dies without heir - and after fifteen years of marriage to your sister, that seems likely - Infante Juan inherits Aragon. Then we face not just a hostile noble but a hostile king on our border."

He pours more wine, thinking hard. "But here's the problem: You're King of Castile, not Aragon. You have no authority over Aragonese succession. It would be like Alfonso trying to make you renounce your claim to Castile. Even if they signed such a renunciation under duress, it would be meaningless. The Cortes of Aragon wouldn't recognize it. The Pope wouldn't enforce it. Alfonso would declare it void immediately."

"The only ways to permanently remove their threat are..." Álvaro pauses, clearly uncomfortable. "Death. Imprisonment for life. Or..."

He stops, then continues carefully. "Or force them into religious orders. A monk cannot inherit a crown. If they took holy vows, genuine ones before bishops, they'd be removed from succession. But forcing that would still likely mean war with Alfonso."

Álvaro walks to the window again. "There's another angle. Your sister María. She's Alfonso's queen. If the male line of Aragon fails, she might have a claim. Some would support a female ruler rather than see the crown pass to brothers who betrayed their nephew."

"But that's all future speculation. Right now, we can only deal with their Castilian rebellion. We can't solve the Aragonese succession problem through this trial."

He turns back to you. "Unless... Juan, what if we offered them a choice? Full pardon and keep their Castilian lands if they voluntarily take religious vows? Frame it as mercy - letting them serve God rather than face execution for treason? It would remove them from both Castilian politics and Aragonese succession."

"Though I doubt they'd accept. They know their value as Alfonso's potential heirs."
And what would happen if I just let them executed? I know that this is harsh, but it is the standard rule for rebellion

Juan is asking about executing the Infantes. This is a serious question about the consequences of applying the standard penalty for rebellion. I need to be realistic about what would happen if he chose this path.

Let me think through the consequences:
1. War with Aragon - almost certain
2. Pope's reaction - would be severe given Juan has papal backing for crusade
3. Castilian nobility reaction - would be shocked and terrified
4. Historical precedent - executing royal princes is extremely rare
5. His sister María's position - she's married to Alfonso V

This would be a catastrophic decision but I should explain why honestly rather than just say "don't do it."

Álvaro goes very still. For a moment, the only sound is the river below. When he speaks, his voice is carefully controlled.

"You could. Legally, you'd be within your rights. They rebelled, seized royal fortresses, refused lawful summons. The sentence for treason is death."

He takes a deep breath. "But Juan... the consequences would be catastrophic. Let me be absolutely clear about what would happen:

Immediately:

Alfonso V would declare war. Not threaten - declare. His brothers' heads would mean Spanish blood for a generation.

Your sister María would become a widow or a hostage in her own court. Alfonso might even blame her.

Every noble in Castile would be terrified. If royal blood doesn't protect the Infantes, no one is safe. Some would rebel out of pure fear.

The Pope would be horrified. You just knelt naked before him, and now you execute princes? He might revoke the crusade bull entirely.

Within weeks:

Aragonese armies would invade from three directions - Aragon proper, Valencia, and Navarre (which Infante Juan rules)

Portugal might join them, seeing an unstable Castile as a threat

France might support Aragon to weaken Castile

Granada would attack our southern frontier while we're fighting Aragon

The realm would tear itself apart."

Álvaro moves closer, his voice urgent. "Juan, I've served your father and you. I've done harsh things to protect the crown. But executing the Infantes would destroy everything. We'd face:

Civil war as nobles choose sides

Foreign invasion from Aragon

Granada conquering the south

Possible excommunication for executing princes who are also Alfonso's brothers

You'd be remembered as the king who destroyed Castile over a failed rebellion that we'd already contained."

He grabs your shoulders. "Listen - Henry IV of England executed an Archbishop once. It destroyed his reputation forever. These are princes of royal blood. Even attempting it... Juan, the men ordered to carry out the execution might refuse. Christian knights executing Christian princes? Some would choose death over that stain."

"Is removing them worth losing your kingdom? Your crusade? Everything?"

events.summary: Juan receives the Granadan delegation in the Alcázar throne room with the papal bull and sacred banner on full display. Ambassador Abu Abdullah al-Zaghal offers doubled tribute, trade privileges, release of Christian captives, and limited missionary access.
