Juan walks from his throne to shake al-Zaghal's hand — shocking the court — but firmly refuses the offer, citing the papal mandate as non-negotiable. He offers conversion as the only alternative. Al-Zaghal respectfully declines, warning that Granada now commands 20,000 soldiers with Maghrebi warriors, Egyptian gold, and Ottoman cannon. He departs noting that Juan's promise to protect surrendered Muslims is 'unexpected and will be remembered.' The diplomatic option is closed; war is inevitable.

exchanges.text:
This is frustrating. But lets not get ahead of ourselves.


Lets focus on bringing them in first and stabilize the realm. 
Lets meet with the nobles in the city this evening. I can confirm the order for their arrest. Can you set this in motion?


Lets now meet with the delegation from Grenada. Or is there something else we need to adress now?

Álvaro visibly relaxes, glad to move away from talk of executions. "You're right. One step at a time. I'll have the nobles assembled in the Alcázar's great hall by sunset - that gives us about four hours. The Archbishop of Toledo will be there, which adds weight."

He moves toward the door, then turns back. "The Granadan delegation... Juan, before you meet them, you should know what they've already shown publicly. They've brought gifts worth at least 20,000 dinars - silks, manuscripts, jeweled weapons. They've been praying openly at their residence, but also visiting our churches, speaking respectfully of Christianity. Their leader, Abu Abdullah al-Zaghal, is no fool. He's been building sympathy."

"They're staying at the Casa de los Abades, the old merchant palace. Shall I send word you'll receive them here in the Torre del Oro, or would you prefer the formal throne room at the Alcázar?"

Álvaro pauses. "Also... Fray Hernando should probably be present. A Granadan peace offer versus a crusade bull - the spiritual implications are significant. And maybe Sir Thomas? He's fought Muslims before, might catch military details we'd miss."

"One more thing," he adds. "The Granadans certainly have spies. By tonight, they'll know you've confirmed the arrest warrant for the Infantes. They'll see Castile as divided, weak. They might adjust their offer accordingly - or try to exploit our division."

He waits for your decision. "Where do you want to receive them, and who should be present?"

I shall take my seat in Alcazar. I will have the papal bull and the banner there on full display.


I shall go there now.

Juan wants to receive the Granadan delegation in the Alcázar throne room with the papal bull and sacred banner on display. This is a power move - showing strength and divine authority rather than meeting them privately. Let me set this scene appropriately.

He's choosing to make this a formal state reception rather than a private negotiation. The timing is interesting - he's doing this before the evening meeting with nobles about the Infantes. 

I should:
1. Describe the preparation of the throne room
2. Set up the impressive display of the sacred items
3. Show the Granadan delegation's arrival and reaction
4. Begin the diplomatic encounter

This is a significant moment - the first meeting between Juan and Granada since he received the crusade bull.

Álvaro nods approvingly. "A formal reception. Good. Let them see the full majesty of Castile and God's mandate. I'll send word immediately and have the throne room prepared."

The Alcázar Throne Room - Early Afternoon

Within an hour, the great throne room of Seville's Alcázar has been transformed. You sit on the throne of Castile, wearing clean white garments with your father's sword across your lap. Behind you, mounted on a tall stand, the white banner blazes in the afternoon sunlight streaming through high windows. The gold reliquary of the True Cross and silver reliquary of Saint James's bone catch the light like stars.

To your right stands Fray Hernando in his simple Hieronymite robes. To your left, Álvaro de Luna in the rich dress of the Constable. Sir Thomas Beaumont stands with the guard, his scarred face impassive. Rodrigo and García flank the banner itself, hands on sword hilts.

The papal bull, with its heavy lead seal, rests on a cushion on a small table beside the throne - visible to all who approach.

Courtiers line the walls. Word has spread quickly, and perhaps sixty nobles and churchmen have gathered to witness this meeting. The Archbishop of Toledo stands among them, watching carefully.

The great doors open. A herald announces: "The embassy of the Sultan of Granada!"

The Granadan Delegation Enters

Twelve men enter in formation. Their leader, Abu Abdullah al-Zaghal, is perhaps fifty, with intelligent dark eyes and a carefully groomed gray beard. He wears rich but not ostentatious robes of deep blue silk. His companions include scribes, two who are clearly military observers, and one who might be a scholar or imam.

They carry three ornate chests - their gifts.

As they advance down the long hall, you see the moment al-Zaghal notices the banner and relics. His step doesn't falter, but his eyes narrow slightly. When he sees the papal bull, his expression becomes even more careful.

He stops at the appropriate distance and bows - correctly, respectfully, but not subserviently.

"Your Majesty Juan, King of Castile and León, I bring greetings from my lord Muhammad IX, Sultan of Granada, Defender of the Faithful, Lord of Málaga and Almería. May peace be upon this gathering."

His Castilian is flawless, with only the slightest accent.

"My Sultan sends these humble gifts as a token of our desire for continued peace between our realms." He gestures, and his men open the chests, revealing:

Bolts of silk that shimmer like water

An illuminated Quran with covers of gold and ivory (bold to bring to a Christian court)

A sword with a damascene blade and jeweled hilt

An astrolabe of brass and silver, incredibly intricate

Several manuscripts on mathematics and astronomy

Al-Zaghal continues: "My Sultan has heard of Your Majesty's... spiritual journey. We congratulate you on receiving the blessing of your Holy Father. Yet we come to remind you that Granada has been home to Muslims, Christians, and Jews for seven centuries. Many arrangements are possible between men of wisdom."

He pauses, choosing his words carefully. "My Sultan offers this: Double the current tribute, from 50,000 to 100,000 gold dinars annually. Free passage for Christian merchants in our lands. The return of all Christian captives currently held - some 300 souls. Permission for Christian priests to minister to Christians living in Granada. All this, in exchange for continued peace."

"Furthermore," his voice takes on a slightly harder edge, "the Sultan wishes Your Majesty to know that Granada does not stand alone. The Dar al-Islam - the house of Islam - has awakened to our situation. Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, even the mighty Ottomans have pledged their support. What might have been an easy conquest a year ago would now be a long, bloody war."

"Yet war serves neither of our peoples. The farmers need peace to tend their fields. The merchants need peace for trade. Mothers need peace to raise their children - both Christian and Muslim mothers weep the same tears for dead sons."

He gestures to the illuminated Quran. "That holy book, which I know Your Majesty will not read, speaks of Jesus - whom we call Isa - as a great prophet. It speaks of Mary - Maryam - with reverence. We are not the pagans your ancestors fought. We worship the God of Abraham, as do you."

"My Sultan proposes this: Let us sign a treaty of twenty years' peace. Your Majesty can claim victory - doubled tribute, freed captives, protected Christians. You can focus on the internal matters of Castile." His eyes flicker meaningfully - he knows about the Infantes. "And in twenty years, perhaps our children will find better solutions than sword and blood."

Al-Zaghal steps back. "This is Granada's offer, made in good faith. We come as neighbors seeking peace, not as subjects seeking mercy. What says the King of Castile?"

The throne room is utterly silent. Everyone watches you. The papal bull gleams beside you, the True Cross blazes behind you, and before you stands an intelligent, dignified man offering you everything except the one thing the Pope commanded - the conquest of Granada.

How do you respond?

I stand up from my throne and walk up to the noble Muslim to shake his hand.


I welcome you and thank you for your moving and spirited appeal. We have lived as neighbours for a long time and there is much we can teach one another.


I point to the papal bull.


In fact our holy father has charged me to ensure both Christians and Muslims live peacefully in Grenada and I take this charge very seriously.


But we cannot deny the constant conflicts there have been along our borders. I have come to put an end to those once and for all and end the constant raiding and tention in our lands. Both Muslims and Christians will live peacefully under christian rule.


I let Diego read the Bull in it's entirely where I stress the treatment of converts and the prohibition of plundering. We conclude with the crusade goals, the conversion of mosques to churches, overthrowing of muslim rule and a te deum in Grenada.


You see my friend, you can convert today and you will fall under my protection. But we christians all know - and a spread my arms wide and gesture to the crowd - that such a command from our holy father and our lord binds us. That is why I must respectfully decline your proposal as it is in direct conflict with my sacred charge and I will never violate that. What you propose is impossible and I hope you understand this.


I wish you well, I truly do. May the light of the lord find you and I hope to one day greet you as fellow christian.


If there is nothing further, go home with my blessing.

Juan is taking a firm but respectful stance here. He's:
1. Showing personal respect by walking up and offering to shake hands
2. Acknowledging the peaceful offer 
3. Having the papal bull read in full to show his position is not negotiable
4. Offering conversion as an alternative
5. Being clear but not hostile
6. Essentially ending negotiations firmly but politely

I need to show how al-Zaghal responds to this - he's intelligent and came prepared for this possibility. The nobles watching will have varied reactions. This is a significant moment.

The throne room stirs with whispers as you rise and walk toward the Muslim ambassador. Several courtiers look shocked - a king leaving his throne to greet an infidel? But al-Zaghal's eyes show a flicker of genuine respect as he takes your offered hand firmly.

As Diego reads the papal bull in its entirety - a full twenty minutes of Latin translated to Castilian - you watch al-Zaghal's face. His expression never changes, but his military advisors exchange meaningful glances at certain passages. The promises of protection for converts, the prohibition of plundering, the requirement for peaceful conversion offers before military action - these are not what they expected.

When Diego finishes with "...a Te Deum sung in the cathedral of Granada," the silence is profound.

Al-Zaghal nods slowly. "Your Majesty honors us with plain speech. Let me return the courtesy." His voice carries clearly through the hall. "You offer me protection if I convert today. A generous offer, personally. But I am a Muslim, as my father was, and his father before him. I will die a Muslim, God willing."

He steps back, addressing you but speaking to the entire court. "You say this is a sacred charge that binds you. I understand. We too have sacred duties. And so I must tell you clearly - Granada will resist. Not from hatred of Christ, whom we revere as a prophet. Not from hatred of Christians, many of whom live peacefully in our lands. But because our faith, our law, our way of life is also sacred to us."

The ambassador's voice takes on a different tone - formal, almost ceremonial: "Since you have been plain, let me be also. Granada is not the isolated city it was. Twenty thousand soldiers gather under our banner. The Maghreb sends its finest warriors. Egypt sends gold. The Ottomans send their great cannon. This will not be the easy conquest of a weak neighbor. This will be war between faiths, and such wars are the bloodiest of all."

He gestures to his scribes, who begin packing the gifts. "We will take these back. They were offered in hope of peace. But know this - we also take back word of a young king who treated us with courtesy, who walked from his throne to shake a Muslim's hand, who promises protection for converts rather than slaughter."

"That is... unexpected. And it will be remembered."

Al-Zaghal bows again. "Your Majesty, I suspect we will meet again, though next time it may be across a battlefield rather than a throne room. I pray that when that day comes, we both remember this moment - when two men of different faiths spoke honestly and parted without hatred."

He turns to go, then pauses. "One thing more. The internal troubles of Castile are known to us. Some in Granada counsel that we should attack while you face the Infantes. But my Sultan is honorable. We will not strike while you settle your house. But once you march south with that banner, once you cross our frontier - then we will fight with everything we have."

"Go with your God, Juan of Castile. You will need Him."

The delegation withdraws in perfect order, taking their gifts. As the doors close behind them, the throne room erupts in discussion.

The Archbishop of Toledo approaches the throne. "Your Majesty... that was remarkably handled. Firm but not insulting. Though I confess, shaking his hand..."

Several younger nobles are energized, talking of crusade and glory. Others look thoughtful - al-Zaghal's warnings about Granada's strength clearly registered.

Álvaro appears at your elbow. "Well done. You showed strength without giving them cause for immediate war. And his promise not to attack during our internal troubles - that's valuable time."

He lowers his voice. "The nobles are assembled for tonight. After what they just witnessed, confirming the arrest order for the Infantes will seem like the natural next step in asserting your authority. Shall we proceed?"

Fray Hernando has been silent throughout, but now speaks quietly: "That man would have been a valuable Christian. But forced conversion is no conversion at all. You did right to let him leave in peace."
